reviews.review_title: Better when it focuses on science
reviews.content: When APOLLO 13, which, to me, is still the best movie about the space program ever, came out, Tom Hanks said something which is still instructive. He said the story was so good in of itself there was no need to go Hollywood on it, and I wish director Joe Johnston had taken that to heart with this movie.  I read the book this is based on, and like this movie, it's best when it focuses on the science part.  It's careful and probing, and it doesn't overwhelm you with jargon talk.  And you get to see the many mistakes before the eventual triumph.  But the rest of the movie falls a little short.  The sentiment was there in the book too, but it wasn't as blunt as it is here.  There are too many cliches, and a few changes(like having the teacher being able to see the final rocket launch from her hospital bed; in reality, if memory serves, she had already died).  I guess I liked this movie, I just wasn't inspired by it like others were, and like APOLLO 13 inspired me.

This movie is a very clean cut, entertaining film.  One aspect I really enjoyed was that very little was changed from actual events, because some plotlines seem "Hollywood".  The main characters could have been developed a bit more, but all in all a very worthwhile film.

"October Sky" is a Biography - Drama movie in which we follow the life of Homer Hickam whose dream was to launch a rocket after he was influenced by the launch of Sputnik. No one believed in him except one teacher and some friends of his who helped him a lot in order to achieve his goal.I liked this movie because it is based on the life of a real person and his story is just amazing. He tried a lot to fullfil his dreams and did everything he could in order to achieve his goals. I also believe that "October Sky" is a good movie that will inspire to chase your dreams too no matter what the others believe.

reviews.review_title: Look at it go, Homer. This movie's gonna go for miles. October Sky is just a beautiful movie. You don't need to be a Rocket scientist to get that.
reviews.content: Based on the memoirs of real life NASA engineer Homer Hickam, October Sky (an anagram for the novel 'Rocket Boys') was indeed a great family film. October Sky also stands for the date, Oct. 4, 1957 where Soviet satellite Sputnik 1 spark the Space race, and Homer Hickam's dreams of building rockets. The reason why October Sky was chosen by the studio over Rocket Boys is because they thought it wouldn't sell with women. Universal Pictures changed the title to be more inviting to a wider audience and thus it did work. Indeed, the title, October Sky has a little more feel to it, than Rocket Boys anyways. In the film, Homer Hickam (Jake Gyllenhaal), a coal miner's son sees this as an inspired to take up rocketry against his father's wishes played by the great actor Chris Cooper as John Hickam. Only Chris Cooper can load that much dignity in silence and fire off like rocket with his body language. Amazing. Just the way, that Jake and Chris's characters butt heads in this movie is intense. Both have fears and reasons to do what they do. Homer's father wasn't cruel, he was old fashioned. Homer was trying to break the mold, John had been in coal mining for his life and he came from a generation grounded. Homer wanted to fly and get out and John couldn't see it. Both characters love each other, father and son wise, but with careers, it was father VS son indeed. This movie is a capable-enough movie on its own right, and it's really serve as a great father's day movie as well. The movie teaches parents to be more open to their children's own plans for their lives, while also the world that is ever so changing. The scene where Homer tells his father who his hero is, is very emotion. Great scene, indeed. The supporting cast was great as well. Homer gets help building with his friends, Quetin (Chris Owen), Roy (William Lee Scott) and O-Dell (Chad Lindberg). It's weird in the book, Homer was more the nerd, and Quetin is the all-around kid and in the film, they change parts and looks. All likable charming American character with some background sub-plot story arches for themselves as well like Roy Lee's abusive foster father. Lot of laughs and smiles to go with their small scenes of their wacky high-jinx. Laura Dern is pretty good as the Miss Riley, the teacher that get them on the right track by helping with their math and science. However, the film does have some drawbacks. I don't think the film capture the joy and triumph of Hickham's original memoir; as it changes things up to make them more dramatic in the film such as Homer going into the mine to work, Homer meeting Wernher Von Braun and the issues with Miss Riley's health. In real life, she actually lived several years after the movie ended. It tend to jazz up the real life events way too much. There was also the fact that the boys were 8 to 14 at the time not 17. Parents would be complaining that the film is showing young children playing with rockets if they show 8 year olds. Also, Homer was more well-known by his nickname 'Sonny' in his hometown, but I think the movie change it for the better. The movie also has this predictable flat formulaic flow to it that you knew was going to happen. Still, you have to have a hard heart, if you're not moved by the film ending. You knew deep inside from the beginning that this will be a good feel movie with uplifting themes. There is great symbolism of how grounded, the community was in the beginning and how rockets change this area for the better. The movie was such a big hit, that an October Sky festival was host in the town, every year since then. One thing I love about October Sky is a warm, evocative soundtrack. Mark Isham did a great job with the main themes. The violin at the beginning gives me goosebumps every time. Also great use of 1950's to early 1960's songs as well to set the mood and settling. These songs just gives me chills and makes me happy and reminds me that from the humblest of beginnings come the greatest of men. Overall: Joe Johnston's film would inspired others to look into their dreams, while also entertain them with the rich intelligence subject matter mixed with the coming of age story drama. October Sky will continue to help launch new dreams for children and adults wishing to become future rocket scientists for themselves. It's a good watch, and worth checking out.

reviews.review_title: A New Model of Inspiration for the Twenty First Century
reviews.content: I must disagree with all the viewers who say that October Sky repeated a familiar theme.  Some of it was predictable, to be sure, but you expect that in this type of movie.  Did anyone for a moment expect Rocky or the Karate Kid to lose at the end of those movies?  Yet they are respected as classics.What makes October Sky special is its quality treatment of intellectual triumph.  We live in the days when children attend designer pre-schools and billionaire nerds outshine even professional atheletes.  Homer and his friends are role models for our new American culture.  October Sky is the first of a new type of movie, a type whose time has come.I highly recommend this movie for these unique qualities, and I hope to see more like it in the future.
This film is so heartbreaking and inspiring and that's what I loved about it. Young Jake Gyllenhaal is so cute and amazing, natural talent.

reviews.review_title: One of 1999's best, and true to boot!
reviews.content: As a teen who launched rockets of his own, I found much to identify with in this touching film.  It is a wonderful movie about persistence in following one's dream.  In addition, it's a great coming-of-age film and deals with the sensitivities of a difficult father-son relationship.  I highly recommend this movie.  It's as delightful for what it does contain, as for what it does not contain.  Truly a family film.

True story told in unassuming fashion about West Virginia "Rocket Boys" who won't stand still for Russian Sputnik launch.  The high-schoolers efforts to build a working missile contrast with their drab life in a working coal mine town.  Never overdone, it's just good, uplifting ensemble work by a largely unknown cast.

reviews.review_title: Must watch for kids,youngsters,parents .. for everybody
reviews.content:
The concept of the movie was just incredible. The cast especially jake gyllenhall,oh god he was awesome. This movie touched the core of my heart and played the strings of my brain .The way characters built over time was pretty nice .Chris cooper who played the dad's role didn't seem like he was acting.Felt so genuine.
End verdict: A must watch inspirational movie

I saw this in a sneak preview double feature with "Patch Adams", which paled in comparison to "October Sky".This is easily the best movie I've seen in a year.  Thoughtful, serious, but at the same time uplifting and fulfilling.  It was such a refreshing change to see a movie deal with both a West Virginia coal town and science without winking at or belittling either one, or for that matter, making one seem any better or more worthwhile than the other.Jake Gyllenhaal delivers a stunning performance as Homer Hickam, and the supporting cast captures the depth and detail of life in a mining town.

The acting in this movie was superb. As an amateur rocketeer, I found very few mistakes. As a human being, it touched my heart and soul. To watch the actors, you would think that they are the actual characters. Laura Dern, a favorite actress of mine, left nothing out of her performance. The young actors playing the Rocket Boys showed talent beyond their years, especially young Homer. Homer's father inspired that eternal love/hate relationship between a father and son so that it felt real. If you don't get a lump in your throat or shed a tear when that first successful rocket goes up or when father and son come to terms, then get your pulse checked (you may be dead).

It is the fault of public majority that movies like this keep getting made whether it's under the name of Seabiscuit, Apollo 13, October Sky, or The Rookie.  These movies are as hollow as they are emotional and as vapid in substance as they are in creativity.These films all repeat the same concepts and questions without letting the audience expand on any thoughts.  They are one-dimensional.  False emotional and sentimentality are a fool's paradise.Overall, skip this.  It's amazing how simplicity can infect the most hopeful of scripts.  1.5 out of 5 stars.

Saw a sneak preview of this on January 26.  It's a good family film that will appeal to youngsters (for the rockets) and their parents (for the late-50's nostalgia).  Mild profanity, but nothing out of the prime-time TV range.  Based on a true story.

reviews.review_title: One of the best films ever!
reviews.content: If you ever have a chance to vote for the best movie ever., please seriously consider October Sky. I first saw it and one touched, watched it again and cried, and rented it and sobbed. This will always be one of the best family films ever. With a roller coaster of emotions, October Sky will make you laugh, cry and and feel good about yourself. Go October Sky!!!

We saw October Sky when it first came out in the theaters. My family all thought this movie was excellent. My teen didn't want to see this movie, but she went with us anyway...and she loved it, too! This is a wonderful film for a family to see together.October Sky is inspirational, uplifting, touching, and humorous. The movie also has a very positive message about the benefits of a good education. Education was the way out and the way up for the boys in this town, which is a good message for all teens.This is the first time we saw Jake Gyllenhaal in a movie, and we were so impressed with him. I am not surprised to see how well his career has progressed.

reviews.review_title: Great true story, great message to always follow your dreams.
reviews.content: I have seen this movie a bunch of times and I can still watch it without getting bored. It is a true story of determination and following your dreams. Jake Gyllenhaal does a great job as the lead and the story line is great and heart felt.This movie is about a young boy in a small coal mining town in West Virginia circa 1950s. The only job in his town for the men is too work in the coal mine but after seeing the Russian satellite sputnik fly overhead he wants to go into space. He gets interested in building rockets and his friends and him build rockets until they actually get pretty good.This movie is really good and its based on a true story which makes it that much more amazing.

reviews.review_title: A beautiful (true) story that everyone should see
reviews.content: Forgotten in a box full of VHS tapes in a school closet somewhere, October Sky is one of those films you forgot you loved during your school days. Revisiting this film shows that it still has its magic.October Sky is a coming-of-age film with a heart of gold. The film follows Homer Hickman Jr., a kid from West Virginia follows what he loves doing -- making rockets.The film shows the rewards of chasing your dreams, no matter how ambitious. Something that I find quintessentially fundamental to the American dream.The film keeps its magic of innocent youth. You will laugh and shed tears of sadness & joy throughout. Acting is solid and convincing. Surprised no one won an Emmy for this. It's that good.4.5/5. A heart-warming film that still keeps its magic after all the years.

This movie was the best and most rewarding film experience for me in 1999. Even after repeated viewings it still makes me champion, and value, the power of the individual to go after a personal goal in life.........not a bad message for anyone, anytime!  My congratulations to everyone connected with this fine film.  Anyone who enjoyed this film should read the book it was based on (also called "October Sky", but originally published as "Rocket Boys"). As much as I enjoyed the movie, the book just blew me away. It was one great and memorable experience just "hangin' out" with the "boys".

An entertaining little movie about a group of four boys growing up in a mining town who become inspired by the space race of the 1950s to build a rocket and win the national science fair. It features a very young Jake Gyllenhaal with solid support from Laura Dern and Chris Cooper. Best of all it's a true story, or at least it's a Hollywood version of the truth so who knows.

I thought that this movie was excellent!!! I was very well casted, written, filmed and directed. The kid who played "Homer" was amazing, and I am positive that great things will come to him!! The entire cast was incredible, as a matter of fact. This movie will most definately remain in my heart for a very, very long time! I don't know how I could ever forget it!!If you haven't seen this movie, you do not know what you are missing. Go Out and Rent It!!!!!!

October Sky is an excellent movie. In addition to having great common themes, i.e., don't give up, don't be afraid to pursue your dreams and don't be a victim of your circumstances, October Sky is an excellent example of what many fathers and sons go through together.I sat down with my son to watch this movie. He loved the pursuit of the dream, the adventure of the boys and at the end, when Homer's father comes to watch the final rocket launch and put his arms around his boy, my son turned and looked at me and understood exactly why I wanted to watch this movie with him. Not many movies can entertain and teach at the same time without being heavy handed. The Director's handling of the father/son relationship was right on.I also love Natalie Cannerday as the mom. I wish she had more opportunity to be put on screen because she has the best accent in Hollywood. I could listen to her twang all day.

There is virtually nothing I didn't like about this film.  Everything in this film is done so very well.  The acting is well executed, the story is excellent, the cast is great, the directing perfect...just an all-around superb movie!What makes this film so great is that it is based on the real life events of Homer Hickam and "The Rocket Boys".  The film is very inspirational and teaches you that if you truly want to fulfill your dreams, GO FOR IT!  Don't just sit around, MAKE IT HAPPEN!The cast is absolutely perfect in this film.  I loved every actor and actress in this film and thought all of them did an excellent job with their roles.  Jake Gyllenhaal is superb as Homer Hickam, I think he's really an "up-and-coming" young actor.  Chris Cooper, Laura Dern, Chris Owen, William Lee Scott, Chad Lindberg, and everyone else really deserve some notice this film.  Job well done!  And let's not forget the directing of Joe Johnston! Joe doesn't seem to make bad movies (although I did have some problems with "Jumanji", but not much), can't wait to see his next work!I would definitely recommend this film to anyone that is interested in a drama about some young men trying to fulfill their dreams.  This really is a great movie, and I hope you will enjoy it too.  Thanks for reading,-Chris

reviews.review_title: I loved this movie.... cried a lot.... a fine story..
reviews.content: I loved this movie completely. Jake Gyllenhaal, before his breakthrough role in Donnie Darko, stars as Homer Hickam, a teenager who in October 1957 decides to build a rocket. This is based on a true story, written by Homer Hickam, of how four friends start to build a rocket in the small city Coalwood, West Virginia, and how they inspire the people of that town by doing the impossible. Except from the story of the building of rockets and how people are both happy and unhappy of it, it is the story of a father and son relation, how a teenager really fights for his dreams, no matter what his father thinks or wants. A beautifully storytelling movie with all glorious moments... that it is a true story makes it more believable, but at the same time also unbelievable.Highly recommended, not only for the fine story but also for fine characters, great actors and a great photography. Forget visual effects - this is a great drama movie with a great story.

October Sky is such an excellent movie. This is one of them movies that families can watch together. October Sky is such an inspirational movie. If you set your mind to something and never give up then your dreams can come true. This movie might not have done good in theaters but it deserves praise. The acting was excellent. This is my favorite fact based movie of all times. I recommend this movie to anyone who has a dream. I also recommend this movie to anyone who loves a good fact based, family movie. you wont be disappointed.

Definitely one of the best movies I've ever watched ! The struggle for realising one's ambitions in face of so many hardships, to keep on pursuing one's objective doggedly and not let your will welt under pressure...... The movie's simple but offbeat storyline amalgamated with the excellent piece of acting by Homer's character makes it worth to watch. Go ahead friend....don't wait now !!

The story told by this movie would seem romanticized, if not for the fact that it is closely based on the truth. The film is surprisingly true to the book, down to the details of Miss Riley's illness and subsequent death. Homer Hickam and his friends really did escape the coal mine to pursue their dreams. They suffered setbacks, took many detours, and endured the scorn of their peers. In the end, they prevailed. The hero's quest is often a lonely one, but can end in success. The film portrays both the adversity and the triumph well.In reading some other reviews, I was saddened to see that people have become so cynical that they cannot imagine that the events happened as they were depicted, that the story was embellished with corny Hollywood cliches. To those individuals, I recommend the book.

reviews.review_title: The feel good film of the year for 1999
reviews.content: A great film, that is uplifting as a young man named Homer discovers that there is no future in a small rural coal town in West Virginia in the late 50's.  All the students either end up in the mine or if they're lucky, will get a football scholarship.  Homer is not stupid and knows the mine has no future even though his coal mining dad believes in it strongly.He suddenly sees an opportunity as the Sputnik satellite launch inspires him to build a rocket.  After some total bad starts he makes friends with an ostracized brain named Quentin in school in hopes of gaining success. As his experiments start gaining notoriety his teacher tells him that there is a local science fair and that he should enter.  If he wins he goes to the State Science fair and winners there get schoolarships.  Homer now sees what he wants to be in life and the science fair offers that: the chance to go to college and become an astronaut.  This a great film as Homer battles against all odds that seem destined to overwhelm him, his father's disaproval, the fact he lives in a nowhere small town where no-one does anything outside the mine, a principal who feels the communities students only future is shoveling coal, and no resources to gain knowledge.Great based on true story.  One overplayed scene prevents perfect rating but you love it anyway (the rocket being seen through the hospital window.)Rating 9 out of 10

Inspiring story about the "rocket boys". I enjoyed not only the story, the actors, the setting, evolution of the characters and their relationships. It is definitely a movie worth watching, especially as it is based on a true story!

October Sky was a nicely made film about growing up in a coal town with an interest in something beyond mining.  The plot was familiar.  A boy has an interest in an activity not typically associated with his class.  He shows promise and is encouraged by an elder but his family doesn't understand nor support him.  A family tragedy occurs that threatens his future success but in the end he triumphs.  The story is familiar and success is in the telling.  How well do the film makers characterize the participates?  Do they seem real?  Do you develop empathy for them?  In this movie they were successful.  Other movies that follow the same formula aren't as successful. Billy Elliot, in my opinion, though of similar plot structure, (substitute ballet for rocketry), was a failure.  October Sky is worth seeing.

Based on astronaut Homer Hickam's autobiographical work "Rocket Boys" this film features Jake Gyllenhaal as teenage Homer who, along with his three friends, became addicted to rocketry and space-science, ignoring other studies and overcoming his father's effort to make him a mine-worker as himself. This true, refreshing coming-of-age drama is not only fantastic for its outstanding storyline and screenplay, but also for fine performances of Gyllenhaal,Chris Cooper as Homer's father and Laura Dern as Homer's teacher, his favorite Ms. Riley.The story is mostly set in a time in the late 60s. And, through the course of the film, life of the common people in the downtown area is well featured. Good to see that the film contains very little amount of complex scientific details. Instead, the film mostly focused on Homer's life and his determination to fight back. It also succeeded to feature separate points of view of other supporting characters like Homer's father, mother, his friend Quentin and Ms. Price independently. In the end it turns out to be a good film, not only a good story. 4/5.

reviews.review_title: Shows that dreams can come if you stay committed to it.
reviews.content: Warm and heavily inspiring movie based on Homer Hickam's novel where the son (Jake Gyllenhall) of a small-town West Virginia coal miner (Chris Cooper) is motivated to go into rockets after seeing Sputnik and getting endless support from friends around the community despite his father's objections.The movie overwhelmed me with its' never-ending respect and care for the characters here instead of the typical Hollywood methods.  "October Sky" pretty much covers all the issues that go on in a small town, especially in the fifties, where the film takes place.  Also, the movie makes a great point in how important a high school education can be.Gyllenhall is solid here as Homer, who's dream of being in NASA is really put to the test.  And he's not alone, Chris Cooper and Laura Dern also stand out with their moving performances here.  If there's anyone is the film who has the toughest and delicate role, it's the father who looks like you want to dislike him, but you can't."October Sky" shows that dreams can come true if you stay committed to it despite the odds.

Based on an inspirational true story this is a lovely film elevated by excellent central performances from the young Jake Gyllenhall, Laura Dern and the always excellent Chris Cooper. Good period detail and soundtrack too.

But can't say it was original - too formulaic. Sure, you can't expect much from a Hollywood tearjerker, but this one, I have to say, was an exception.Consider the negatives here before we get to the positives. Predictable. (If you know what the movie's about, then you know the outcome. There's a contest. Who wins? That won't take long to figure out.)Some of the confidante/confidants in the story were super nice people and helped the characters get through their mission. Those characters are so nice, that the writers give them an illness or even a death and we're able to feel sympathy. This will defintely dingle with your heart strings, but it's not an original cinematic element. Let's get to the positives. You wanted these guys to succeed.The characters were extremely interesting, and believable. The performances were first rate, and the direction was very good.If you don't look at this with a nitpicking perspective, you'll like it. Just remember, though...no new material, just a good two hours of sappy Hollywood entertainment.

Although you probably won't hear anybody brag about seeing October Sky this movie is a definite see. If you're looking for action or a Rambo movie you need glasses because the most action you will ever see is probably the rocket launches. However this was a good movie otherwise and it should be a must see on your list.

OCTOBER SKY is the best movie I've seen in recent memory, and one of the few that I'd be very happy to see again.  Heck, maybe even a third time.  This is about character, not attitude.  The actors in it look and talk like real people, and although the performances are uniformly excellent there's not a single instance where an actor is center stage for an "Oscar clip" scene at the expense of the other characters.For years people have said that Hollywood should make movies like this.  Well, folks, here it is.  Go see it, and enjoy, because it offers something good for viewers of all ages.

reviews.review_title: This movie soars above the rest
reviews.content:
This film caught me by surprise. My friend told me that this movie was a "chick flick." Boy, was he wrong! This movie has a great family appeal, with no sex scenes like _other_ movies. Jake Gyllenhaal does an excellent job in Homer Hickam's shoes. The supporting cast is great, as well.
Science, coming-of-age, family quarrels, a great train scene... This film has it all. The soundtrack is good, although the score is presented quite choppily. The 50s music kicks the movie over the edge of greatness.The DVD is definitely worth its weigh in coal. Replay value is great - I've seen it quite a few times already.

reviews.review_title: October Sky Will Make You Proud To Be An American!
reviews.content: October Sky is a movie not to be missed. It has all of the elements that make it a great film. A great performance from Jake Gyllenhaal who plays Homer Hickam, a boy growing up in a poor coal mining town in Tennessee in the late 1950s. The boy is inspired by the launching of the Russian Sputnik in October of 1957 and decides, with encouragement from his teacher, played by Laura Dern, to go after his dream of working on rockets in the space program. Homer's father, played by Chris Cooper, is sure that both of his sons should work the coal mines as he did. The whole movie centers around his high school years and how he slowly realizes his dreams of going to college and becoming one of this countries most capable rocket scientists. The fine direction of Joe Johnston must be mentioned. You will also enjoy the score in the background of the late 50s rock 'n roll tunes. You will laugh and you will cry. The story is true. Please don't miss October Sky.

This film was absolutely BRILLIANT!! Every performance in this film is excellent, especially Jake Gyllenhaal and Chris Cooper. It looks like Mr Gyllenhaal will have a HUGE  film career if this is anything to go by. I thought that Joe Johnston was an odd choice as director as he is usually associated woth big budget blockbusters(Jumanji, Honey I shrunk the kids). He pulls of every scene with sheer class. My favourite scene was where Homer is going down the mineshaft and looking at the sky, going down, as all of his dreams were, it was beautiful. Joe Johnston should direct more of these brilliant, acting driven films as well as his Big budget blockbuster faire, which is also excellent. KUDOS!! to all involved in this masterpiece!

reviews.review_title: Sometimes one dream is enough to light up the whole sky.
reviews.content:
I really wish that I was born earlier than I was. Not to be able to see some timeless classic movies when they first appeared on the big screen, but to have seen and heard some of the more famous events in our life time. October Sky' focuses on an event that I had never heard of, but If I was born in the right era, I am sure it would have had an influence on individual just like me. This is an inspirational story, that can and will leave you stunned on what you can achieve, if you put your heart and soul into it. In Coalwood, West Virginia, 1957, coal mining is king and no one can escape life underground. But when high school student Homer Hickam, Jr. sees the Soviet satellite Sputnik streak overhead, he aims for the stars and a new destiny in this incredible true story of hope, determination and triumph. With the help of his teacher and three buddies, Homer sets out to build his own rocket. How Homer overcomes seemingly impossible obstacles-poor education, a disapproving father and a series of misfires that threaten to flatten his dreams and the town- and fulfills his vision is the launching pad for one of the most timeless, inspirational stories ever brought to the screen.Jake Gyllenhaal was terrific as the main star of October Sky'. Homer Hickman, must be an extraordinary personality, and I am sure he would be proud of the performance Gyllenhaal did to this role in a film based on him. Yet I also feel that the boys that backed Homer in his rocketing adventures were also important to the make up of this film. The other young star I know in this movie is who played the character Quentin. He is a good young actor, who has been in the infamous `American Pie' movies. In this film he was completely different, in that he was the nerdy type of guy that everyone avoided at school, yet he also helped pull off what was an amazing feet by such young people.Chris Cooper is the conservative father in this film. In all his films I have found him to be an extremely stubborn character, and he does that in October Sky. He was born to be a very reluctant character. This role reminds me so much of the role he took in the brilliant, American Beauty'. The other good role in this film was that of Homer's teacher, Miss Riley. Out of all the hindrance the boys get to there dream, they have a help in a teacher that wants them to succeed. Miss Riley was portrayed well by Laura Dern.I really felt that this story, though it was based on true life events, was a great premise for a movie. Having the real Homer Hickman write a book really helps the story, then to recreate the time that it was set in, was extremely satisfying for me. I believe the director, Joe Johnston, got the whole mood of the  story just how it was meant to be. I also like how we get to see what the real characters are up to in the end of the film.
To say that October Sky is one of the better films that will uplift and inspire everyone' is pretty obvious. Yet this film also shows me that movies based on true stories can be extremely invaluable, as it can show how great some people really are, if they put their mind to it. This film also proves that parents are not allows right when it comes to knowing what there children want. Instead it makes me certain that parents need to help, rather than hinder there children, because if they don't it could result in people never knowing how great some young people can be. CMRS gives October Sky': 4.5 (very good  brilliant film)

Usually a great movie consists of big epics (i.e. SAVING PRIVATE RYAN) or big director's with a big budget (TITANIC).  Then sometimes you get those special little movies, the great movies because they have a good story and good acting.  "October Sky" falls in the latter, it's a terrific movie that doesn't need effects or the works ofa famous director to make it a great movie.  Instead  the story and characters make it a unique movie, about four young boys who live in a mining town in West Virgina during the launch of Sputnik.  One of the boys, Homer (Jake Gyllenhaal), dreams of making a rocket ship that can one day, go into space.  His father, played by Chris Cooper (my favorite character actor along with Sam Neil) disapproves of this idea and wants young Homer to take over the coal mines when he's older. Following his heart instead of his dad, Homer recruits his two friends, and the school nerd, to build and test rockets. To their surprise, the entire town becomes excited about their project. This is a movie that explains to the viewer that one should follow their heart for what they want to do.  This movie is emotional, both good and bad. I'm sure it won't win any Oscars next year, but it will be remembered as a great movie (like THE NATURAL).  A very entertaining film that is great for the family!

This was the film that made me a "Gyllenhaalic". I just loved Jake's work in this film. I liked the film and the story so much, I even read the book by the real Homer Hickam called "The Rocket Boys", which was the original name of this movie but Universal decided to change it to "October Sky". I do like the name "October Sky". Anyway, Jake's performance was his best to date. I have just seen "Jarhead" recently and it was awful. But then again, I don't like military films. I think that I'll always like "October Sky" unless Jake does a film better than this but I don't know if he could top this film but I don't doubt it. Even the trailer to "October Sky" is sort of a tear-jerker. I have seen a lot of Jake films from "City Slickers" to "Jarhead" but this one ranks as his GREATEST to date. I love this film!!!!

reviews.review_title: Not a good film, but a GREAT film!
reviews.content: This is one of the best films I have seen in quite some time.  Beautifully and lovingly made, the script never lets you down.  I seldom cry at a movie, but the end left me in tears.  This is a film for the entire family to see. I know that when it comes out on video, I will add this to my library.  I couldn't recommend this more.

This is a wonderful movie about a young man with a dream. I don't know about everyone else, but it reminded me of the dreams I had when I was kid growing up. I lamented that I didn't have the same persistence and drive that he had.It also reminded me of other movies about a person or persons following their dream against tremendous odds. I gave each of these movies a 9 also: Rocky, Rudy & Hoosiers - all sports movies. Another similar movie was Tucker: A Man And His Dreams. The only problem with it was that it had an unhappy ending.The wonderful thing about October Sky was that it was emotionally uplifting unlike very few films even attempt to be. Symbolically, the greatest moments of the film were when his rockets shot straight into the air - the same as our spirits.If you want an outstanding feel-good movie to see, this is it.

Warm and touchy human story. By far the best film of Jake Gyllenhaal I've seen. Chris Cooper acting very convincing as usual, which intensify the emotions that the movie plot brings. Pretty good casting, very realistic picture of the States back in the 50's on the small mining province in the middle of nowhere. Very good set of events and smooth developing of characters as from the old Hollywood school, I would say. Carefully ignored political background of that time has been done extremely smart and in favor of the plot: first human satellite in space is the greatest world achievement, even though Soviet, and most of the Americans that weren't scared of that new Russian space power were cheering it, or even being proud of that world accomplishment. Moving.

reviews.review_title: This just hit a chord in me
reviews.content: I just got done watching October Sky and it blew me away.  I am a sucker for most movies about a kid with dreams fighting to make his dream a reality. And I don't usually get tearry eyed, but I had tears of joy throughout this film because I could see myself in these characters.  I grew up in a small town and could empathise with them. So all in all, go see this amazing movie.  You will not be disappointed.  I gave it a 10.

reviews.review_title: The backdrop propels this inspiring tale of a kid who followed his passion and the people who helped him achieve it
reviews.content: If I had to define this movie in one word it would be: aspirational. Regardless of whether it sticks to the truth in every single detail of the tale, there's no denying this movie portrays the inspirational story of an underdog kid trapped in a town too small and small-minded for his ground-breaking dream.Maybe it's because, as an engineer from a small town myself, I relate to this sort of tales too closely; but I strongly believe this movie succeeds in what it's trying to say even though it's based in a true story. I'm reluctant to trust all that a biographical picture shows about a historical figure's life, however if it recounted with little changes and it is focused on a positive outcome, I can't help but praise it.Something that caught my attention was that it doesn't idealize neither the negative nor the possitive aspects on such an initiative of the kids. There are folks trying or finding ways to stop them from carrying on or mocking what they are trying to achieve but it never goes too far in terms of stepping out of the realm of the plausible as Hollywood sometimes has. In real life no situation or person is entirely bad or entirely good, we are motivated by our own morals and interests. However, that doesn't mean bad things happen.As you watch the movie it's clear that it's based on a true story because the pacing and unfolding of events feels very "self-controlled" in the sense that it never romanticises many of the themes and tropes presented in it. And that only enhances the realism of the story it is trying to tell. But mainly the themes it presents may be its strongest suit. The theme of the father who has lived his whole life in a coal town and can't fathom the idea that his son wants to build rockets and go to space when such a thing was not only possible for a handful of people from probably bigger cities or with better education, but also impossible at the time. I believe the backdrop of the movie and therefore the story, is so inspiring because it was a time were very few believed in the reaches of technology. TV and radio was barely just invented a decade or so ago and it was becoming revolutionary.Surely, if it wasn't based on a true story, I'd find the fact that a coal-miner's son who suddenly develops an interest in rockets and is capable of learning the advance mathematics and be able to achieve what he does in the movie, very hard to believe. But because those aspects of the movie are taken from real life it is way more commendable and trully inspirational. And that's just it, this movie feels unreal for how far kids from a small town go in the space race and all that happens to them, and it makes you wonder why this story hasn't been told before.Additionally, the subplots are not romanticised like other 50s-based movies have because the true story takes center focus. However, the addition of the romantic and other supporting characters subplot provide more layers to the story and emotional weight on many occasions through out the film. Like I said before, regardless of whether those things really happened or not, they enhance the more dramatic or victorious scenes in their own way.But that's the beauty of it, while the dramatic and dream-obstructing scenes weigh down the aspirations of this young kids, these are balanced out by the victory scenes where the inclusion of many of not only the supporting characters but the whole town and other witnesses of the greatness this kids are achieving, elevates the sense of success and inspiration of this moments.IN CONCLUSION, I've tried to keep out of talking about many plotpoints and themes as I believe this are sort of expected from a movie with such a premise but also because I believe it is part of the charm of the movie, the messages it presents in every turn. I may have not being objective when reviewing this title, but that's because as an engineer from a small town in south Spain, I've lived in a town with close-minded people where I had some good but mostly unfortunate moments in my childhood. But I managed to get out of there and find a future for myself, and I don't look back at it with resentment as if I hadn't had the life I had there, well, I wouldn't be were I am now.This movie is deeply inspirational for those who dream of leaving their current life in pursuit of greater things. They don't have to be building the first rocket, becoming president of a country, building the next computer, it need only be a personal dream born from a passion and the perception of the world we live in. It is hard, I know, you may be drawn to believe everything is already invented and everything has already been done, but that doesn't mean you won't find something else on your way. Inspiration and ideas are born from not only what we know but the questions we ask when we know what has already been done. That's how it was done then, reading up books about rocket scientists, and that's how it works now. Know what exists to ask about what doesn't.

Saw this movie first in the sixth grade. Our engineering teacher was trying to inspire us. It did not work at the time lol. But it is surely inspiring now.This movie really gave me a glimpse into another side of America, a side that I don't think much about. Makes me feel blessed to have had the upbringing that I have had. The movie nails the feel of this coal mining town perfectly, and encapsulates the the trapping feeling of the town. This makes the movie all the more inspiring when Jake Gylenhalls character breaks the mold. It's a very inspiring movie, and shows how a little vision can enable greatness in ANYONE. Yes you heard it hear folks. ANYONE can be great. Good movie.
My one criticism would be a lack of character relationship development between certain characters. Namely between Homer and his girlfriend, and Homer and the russian coal miner fella who died.

reviews.review_title: A powerful argument for more "true-story" movies
reviews.content:
Much of what has been praised in this movie--the three-dimensional characters, the spot-on historical background, the realistic storyline--can be accounted for by the fact that it is based on an actual story.
Given that nearly everything worked so well in this film, perhaps scriptwriters should in future turn more to actual, well-documented incidents from real life, and quit trying to remake fairy-tales, legends, and ghost stories.It is true that the ending was somewhat predictable. In a way, it might have been a more interesting (but vastly more tragic) movie if Homer and friends had not won at the science fair, and they all ended up working in the mine after all. But this perhaps reinforces my point--for there are no doubt hundreds of failures, in real life, for every Homer Hickam success story.9/10

I haven't read the book but I've seen the film several times.A group of teenage boys get inspired to build rockets with the backing of their science teacher.You'll feel like you've lived with the family after seeing this movie. The over working Dad with responsibilities for family and the entire mining community. The mum who's set aside her own dreams to raise her children. Two sons with aspirations to get to college and away from the certainty of mining work.It doesn't stretch your emotions very far but it does make you think and will keep you entertained throughout.

October Sky (an anagram of Rocket Boys, the name of the book the movie is based on and the fact that Sputnik flew over an October Sky -- pretty neat) is a story about a kid named Homer Hickam (Jake Gyllenhaal) who doesn't seem to have much talent and is destined to work in the town's coal mine, following the footsteps of his father John (Chris Cooper). The one thing he has going for him is determination.At a gathering to watch Sputnik, he sees that little dot move through the sky and is captivated. He wants to build a rocket and he's going to. That single-minded determination will ensure that happens.I think what's so wonderful about this movie is how things are stacked up against him and it's his will that allows him to succeed.
He's not initially smart. he's not into math or science.
He's from a family where his destiny seems set -- work in the coal mine with his father.
The principal thinks he's a waste of time.
The school kids think the rocket thing is a waste of time
His dad is dead set against the hobby. Why waste time on that when the coal mine is right next door.One by one, and with the help of some friends, he overcomes the obstacles. And, one by one, the adversaries turn into allies. The kids who ridiculed him start to root for him. the principal who thinks he's a waste now thinks he's got talent. One by one, he wins them over, by his sheer will to succeed with this rocket.Look, I know not everything is as simple as "follow your dreams and you'll succeed". But I also know more than a few people who wish for something but don't *want* something. They won't work at it, through good times and bad, day and night, over and over until they succeed. And that's what's so incredibly inspiring about this movie. This kid, with no seeming talent, no innate gift for math or science, had so much determination and will that he succeeded. And, while I'm sure there are some Hollywood liberties made, this is based on a true story, so it's not like this is some fantasy that could never happen.This movie should be required viewing for kids in high school. If you liked The Martian or Hidden Figures, this movie is in the same vein and we need more movies like this.

reviews.review_title: A real story with good characters
reviews.content: Originally written 20 February 1999; account moved.Now, this is a story. It is easy to come to like the characters in this film. It is a strangely warm, thoughtful, caring movie about the trials and tribulations of growing up among the vast bluecollar yesteryear of the late 1950's and of a few young men who dream and strive for a better life. All of the actors and actresses here deserve a round of recognition. Bravo.

I was one of the fortunate ones to see October Sky at a sneak preview this past weekend.  It is a very good movie that has a very uplifting message. It teaches us all that no matter who we are or where we come from, anything is possible in life if we put our minds to it.  I suggest this one for the family.  Very enjoyable!

Homer Hickam (Jake Gyllenhaal), a high school kid in a rural mining town, seems headed for the coal mine, just like his father John (Chris Cooper), and is content with that life.  This changes when the Soviets launch Sputnik into space.  Homer gains the desire to build his own rockets, something his father thinks is silly.Homer and his friends Quentin (Chris Owen), Roy (William Lee Scott), and Sherman (Chad Lindberg) seem determined to build their rocket, failing many times.  But their teacher Ms. Riley (Laura Dern) lends some support, believing the boys are onto something.Based on a true story, this is a wonderful little film.  It's nice to see some quality family entertainment now, since all the attention goes to things you can't see with the kids and most non-R rated movies just plain suck nowadays.  The writing is great, while the directing is ok.  The acting is better than in most films, especially Chris Cooper, who is one of the most underrated performers in Hollywood.  This is definetly worth seeing.

Simply loved this movie. Very beautifully told and very inspirational. This movie teaches us to believe in ourselves and never give up. Jake Gyllenhaal and the rest of the cast delivered a wonderful performance. Great direction by Joe Johnston.

Homer was a smart student. After watching Soviet Union successfully launched the rocket, he decided to make his rocket. But that is opposed to his father's will that wished him become his successor in the mine. Under warm encouragement from Homer's teacher, he kept on making rockets. To win the prize in the national science festival would be his last straw.A child should have the right to choose his future. As parent, they should not interfere. Even failed, that is only the price for growing or regret for life.Chris Cooper and Jake Gyllenhaal convincingly played father and son. Their interaction was the most wonderful thing in the movie. Jake also had an impressive show in Donnie Darko (a excellent movie). Although I have not watched Brokeback Mountain, I am sure that he will not disappoint me.A uplifting and touching drama. 9/10

I have to laugh, imagining trying to plug a movie about a bunch of kids from a coal mining town entering a science fair. Sounds like an episode of The Simpsons, right? But October Sky works. It's smart, funny, and uplifting without being cloying or hokey. My kids and I walked out of the theater with more chuzpah than we walked in with. When is the last time watching a movie did anything but rot your mind like candy rots your teeth? Go see is while you have the chance.

I avoided this movie for a long time because it was more or less sold as an inspirational-type film, which made me think of saccharine Pax-TV fare. Then I wound up renting it one night on the suggestion of a friend. I stand corrected.I wound up watching it about 10 times and enjoyed it more and more with each subsequent viewing. It *is* an inspirational-type film, no lie there ... but it's also well-made, well-acted, and beautifully photographed, and has a great soundtrack that combines some great early rock 'n' roll classics with a nice fiddle score. I also thought it was a nice to see a film in which a bunch of young men use their brains instead of their brawn (if any) ... that's what'll get you further in life than anything.

I always enjoy watching this movie from time to time. It's just a good film about never giving up on your dream. The acting is believable. The characters unique. May even bring a tear or two to your eye.

I was 15 when Sputnik was launched. I remember well the reaction it caused. This flick is NOT like "Field of Dreams." For one thing, it is not fiction. If you believe as I do, that the only good thing about the so-called good old days is that they're gone, then watch this movie. If you think the good old days were indeed the good old days, watch it anyway. In other words, watch it, even if you come from a hyper-sophisticated part of the country. It's worth it...

I really didn't want to see this film - I have a real aversion to "you will believe a man can fly/ take your passion and make it happen" movies. My husband is even more inspirational hoo-ha shy than I am. But we needed a movie to go see with his Mom. The kids were great - even Laura Dern was bearable - and that Chris Cooper can act and has some kinda sex appeal despite the dirt and grime and not-so-pretty face.Again, I saw "Trainspotting" four times (bought the soundtrack too!)and I loved this film almost as much.

I loved this film, it's simple and you've seen it all before, that'svery true, but this time it's done well. Young Homer (get it?) sets offon his journey of discovery and it's a joy to watch. His troubledrelationship with his father is pitch perfect, as it is with hisfriends. Inspirational without being sappy, this is like those old greatfilms of Barry Levinson. Very little schmaltz and a lot of heart. Rentit, you'll love it.

If you like authentic stories, based on the lives of real people, filmed on location, then you'll like OCTOBER SKY.  Everything about this film rings true, from the West Virginia accents to the 1957 era clothes and cars. The acting can't be beat.  Everyone is excellent--so good that it is difficult to point to one star.While there are a few well chosen swear words from Homer's coal miner father, that is all that can be said is not family fare.  But this is far from a sugar-coated look at life; existence in a mining town is difficult, and the work of coal miners is not stinted in this film.  Perseverance, blood, sweat, and tears win out in the end, but it sure wasn't it easy.Go along for the trip; you won't be disappointed.

reviews.review_title: Easily, one of the best movies ever made!
reviews.content: After watching this movie, your life is better somehow! Chris Cooper is amazing. Intense masculine energy as Homer's father. This is a story of shame if you understand shame. Why can't Homer's dad simply accept that his son is different than him? What is his block as a man? This is very true to life stuff. We know the theory of Multiple-Intelligences today. Humility would have given his father this insight--the simple attitude that my son is hardwired differently and embrace his brilliance. His father should have been proud of him, but his shame was too powerful. He tried to conform his son in his own image, and a strong willed boy rebels against this. Life gives another "parent" figure (Homer's teacher) as a guide post. The shame Homer's father had is about his own father--pride is rooted somewhere in this story deep inside. Homer's father felt trapped in this mining career, and when he saw his son want to break free, he was gripped with his own fear of leaving; "I had to stay here, so you should as well!" "I didn't get the opportunity, so why should you!" "I had to suffer, so you should as well!" Few men are this aware of honest, but the message is clear.

I saw that movie few days ago. This movie is so great that it makes me feel that if you want something really bad that you have always dreamed about it - you can have it. This shows a big wish come true trought happiness and sadness, hopeless and failure. But if you are strong enough and your heart really belongs to something that you love you can make things different and be happy.

I can't believe it took me this long to see this movie, especially since I like Jake Gyllenhaal and Chris Cooper. Cooper is a miner in a mining town in West Virginia and Gyllenhaal, who plays his son doesn't want to go into the family business. He wants to be a rocket scientist. It's based on a true story. It's no academy award winning movie, but it's very charming and so is Jake Gyllinhall. He's very young in it. The acting by everyone in it is adequate. Everything about it technically is adequate. There's a fun little montage of them shooting, or trying to shoot of their rockets and failing over and over. The sound track was all 60's music which was enjoyable. Although a little predictable and a little derivative it was still pretty entertaining and enjoyable. Maybe because it's just so disgustingly feel good. I cried despite myself at the end. It's also just one of the most family oriented movies ever. If you have the whole family over and don't want to offend anyone, this is the perfect movie for that occasion. There's footage of the real people at the end of the movie. It's pretty fascinating.

reviews.review_title: A film to be inspired by, even if you don't like rockets.
reviews.content: What a delightful film October Sky is.I haven't submitted a review before this one, and while I've seen many films, I feel some films deserve a little extra help as they may not have what has come to be known as "mass appeal".Whether people realize it now, or later on video, they will probably find this film to be worth their while and enjoy it.It also goes to prove that you don't need to get big name actors to tell a story in an engaging manner and execute it with excellence, what remains to be seen is if the film-going public will support such an action.For me, most films that depict a story of triumph over the odds have a chance at winning me over, the fact that this film is based on a true story only makes it more endearing.But more importantly, the theme of perseverance is one that I've personally come to appreciate more than others. Another fine example of such a sentiment can be found in the recent film "Gattaca".I hope you see and enjoy this film. K.

I was just going to vote on this film I gave it a 10 when I saw an average review right on the vote page unacceptable, I keep telling people about this movie one couple called me at midnight to tell me thank you for telling them about it. my wife loves it also so lets not call it gender specific.and as one review called it Hollywood predictable it is based on a true story. so Hollywood can't take the blame on this onewell acted well written charming movie.

If you liked the film Rudy, if Hoosiers made you stand up and cheer, you will love October Sky. Unlike the other two, October Sky is not a sports film. What all three films do have in common is well-told stories of people with dreams who struggle against the odds.The setting for October Sky is a small mining town in West Virginia. In October of 1957 the world learns that the Soviet-made satellite Sputnik has been successfully launched. It is at this point that high-school student Homer Hickam decides to learn all he can about rockets. What begins as a hobby soon becomes an obsession. With the aid of three of his friends, and the encouragement of one of his teachers, Homer learns how to build model rockets.As his passion for the subject develops, Homer senses a life-calling in the making. Unfortunately, Homer lives in one of those towns, where your vocation is determined at birth. Homer's father in particular believes his son is destined to make a living toiling in the coalmines, just like his father. This establishes the central tension in the film, and provides some opportunities for poignant interactions between father and son.This is not a new theme, and the film contains more than a few stock characters. We have already seen the high school teacher played by Laura Dern (think Michelle Pfeiffer in Dangerous Minds or Barbara Hershey in Hoosiers. There is also the high-school principal as uncaring bureaucrat, and a chorus of townsfolk who, at first, remind Homer and the other rocket boys that they should accept their fate in life in the coalmines.In spite of the formulaic nature of the story, this story works. There are enough nuances added that the characters are, at the same time, familiar and new to us. There are no top box-office stars in the film, but there are solid performances by some excellent actors-especially Laura Dern, Jake Gyllenhaal as Homer, and Chris Cooper as Homer's dad.October Sky is based on a true story, and this is part of its power. The image of Homer shooting for the stars while his father dutifully toils in his subterranean world is rich in symbolism. Several years ago, while walking around a Hispanic community on the North side of Chicago, I saw a mural that said, "there are two things we need to give our children-roots and wings." October Sky is about finding that balance. In the beginning of the film, Homer's dad only sees the need for roots, while Homer's thoughts all turn toward flying. Watching the struggle unfold is a richly rewarding experience that the whole family can enjoy.

This is definitely one of the most brilliant family movies ever made. My dad and I saw part of it on an eighth grade trip to Washington D.C. I later watched the trailer for it on this site and that alone was enough to move me to own it. This was definitely a great way to launch (no pun intended) Jake Gyllenhaal's career and one of the best movies, if not THE best, that he will have ever done. If you look at Gyllenhaal's profile and click on the genre section, you will see that "October Sky" is (so far) the only family work he has ever done. To me that is a sad but true illustration of the choices that some actors and actresses make these days and they should do these more often. The movie doesn't entirely feel like a family movie due to a bit of rough language, so I am taking away two stars.

This was a second choice show when the other movie was sold out. What a wonderful surprise to see a movie like this.  It is not only a true story but one that actually makes you feel good inside.  Please set through the credits to see the actual photos of the characters then and now! The was a 9.5 out of 10!

Living on a dying Space Coast, this movie is a reminder about the motivation to go into space. The desire to explore. The story is about 17 year old Homer Hickam living in a coal mining town that's going through many crises's, including deaths, strikes, and ultimately shutting down. But Homer, the one kid who used to be the laughing stock redeems himself by bringing a dying town together on one dream, to go into outer space. Sadly I wish it could be the same for the Space Coast. I wish this movie could bring back the inspiration to these people here. But this movie is at my #1 spot. I don't care how epic "Transformers Dark of the Moon" was, or how awesome "Armageddon" was, October Sky, the movie that's not epic, the movie, that is my all time favorite. It's theme's, it's lesson exceeds all things EPIC and creates another level of EPIC it's self. Even though there isn't meteors or robots or explosions. I highly recommend this movie to anyone of all ages.

What a screen gem! The true story of four boys, centered around Homer Hickam, who bond together to build a rocket as they try to win a science fair that will give them college scholarships and get them out of the coal mine town they live in. Using a cast of unknowns for the roles of the four boys, and Chris Cooper as the unyielding and demanding father of Hickham, as well as Laura Dern as the teacher who both inspires and encourages the boys, the makers of this film made something more than a congratulatory film about someone who made something of his life coming from less than ideal circumstances. To watch this movie is to see what moviemaking is supposed to be about. Telling a good story.

Please don't get me wrong.  It would be a serious injustice to reduce October Sky to an overused cliche.  The movie is a wonderful experience of the United States, the West Virginia coalfield to be exact, in the late '50's.  From the opening scenes watching Sputnik cross the night sky to family relationships to school settings and friendship between young men and women it has the "feel" of the era. The cinematogaphy, soundtrack, writing, and characters are all excellent.  This being a true story makes it all the more impressive.  The cast was great even though none are household names.  Not once in the almost two hours did I think of those I was watching as actors.  The story is truly inspirational in that does show what is good about people----hard work, goal setting, persistence, value of family, friendship, and community.  It also emphasizes the value of education.   This is a movie that should be seen by families. I would like to thank all involved from the real people to the actors and everyone involved in the making of this film.  If it were up to me October Sky would be required viewing.  Four Stars!!!!

reviews.review_title: O what memories it stirred up!!!
reviews.content:
I was born in 1955 and was raised in Kimball, W.Va. I graduated fron Welch High School in 1974 and I too was a Geek. October Skys showed Southern W.Va. in a complex and gentle light. Good hardworking people that loved their families through good and trying times.
The coal mines weren't for everyone and it showed that too. I liked that iit showed Education as very important and caring teachers too.

reviews.review_title: A movie you can watch with your parents, grandparents, children, and all will enjoy.
reviews.content: An inspirational story based on a true story.  The movie focuses mostly on a high school student in the early 1950's, who lives in a small, poor mining town, trying to pursue a personal interest in model rockets.The story is sweet, uplifting, inspirational, and mostly predictable.  We do know it is based on a true life story after all, and they don't base too many stories on people pursuing an interest and failing horribly.I felt the real focus of the movie was the father, John played by Chris Cooper. He clearly was a "responsible" typical middle American person. I think it showed a person struggling with the responsibilities of his job, and his family and trying to make the best choices possible. His job was dangerous, but he was up every day working hard. He tried to channel his son's interests into areas that he (the father) was comfortable with, but the son was resistant to. The movie captures the conflict of a father trying to guide his son, while still allowing him to grow into his own. Ultimately he allows his son some freedom to pursue his own interests, despite the feeling as if his son may be growing apart from him.  In one of the touching moments of the movie, the son lets him know that, that could not happen, when the father says mockingly "So, you met your hero, and didn't even know it." and the son responds "He is not my hero." leaving the implied "you are" hanging on the air.

reviews.review_title: Movie that touches your heart and brings tears in your eyes
reviews.content: I am not someone who writes reviews about movies, but then this is my first experience as I couldn't stop myself writing about October Sky. This movie is very close to my heart as it touches every aspect of our lives – aspiration, family, friends and most of all hope. I guess I have now lost the count of me viewing of this movie and trust me every single time I watch it , my heart feels good and my eyes have tears.The most beautiful part of the movie is the father-son relationship. Like Homer, I have grown up watching my dad as my Hero and always wanted to be someone like him, but could never muster the courage to tell him what he means to me. The other thing I love about this movie is the persistence by which one should follow his heart. Watch it with your family and friends and celebrate life in the way it should be. Show it to your kids, for the values it carries. Sad we do not get to see such stuff these days. Rare gem that is not found these days.

First of all....I liked it. You might be wondering what type of film is this...well, put simply...it is a feel good movie. It makes you feel good for a few reasons: watching a family grow and struggle as they deal with each other's individuality; knowing that sometimes dreams do come true; and that even the most stubborn person can change. Here is a story of a second child who is lost in a family structure that focuses on the accomplishments of the elder sibling and rewards the younger sibling only when he does exactly what is expected of him (no matter how low those expectations may have been.) This is the true story of a young man and his friends who dreamed they could reach the stars (literally) and someday be the people they wanted to be. The story takes place in a small mining town in West Virginia where only a select few of the youth accomplish their goal of leaving the town's borders to follow their dreams. You will follow four of the town's youth as they learn about rockets, science, and life. The film does lack some depth in the area of seeking emotional ties with the audience, but that doesn't really hurt the film, it just doesn't enhance the quality of it. Bottom line...if you like films like "Rudy", "Field of Dreams", "Lean on Me", and "Stand By Me" then you should see this one.

reviews.content: This movie is a complete heart warmer. It just makes you feel good about yourself. I left the theater with a smile on my face and a warm feeling in my heart. Since I'm only going to echo the praise everyone is giving, I'll keep this short.  How incredibly refreshing to see that teenagers are not as superficial the media seeks to portray.  There are no real surprises in the denouement, but the fact that October Sky is still so enjoyable makes it all the more greater.  Nicely done all around.One dissenting critic wrote that only Republicans and fans of Norman Rockwell will like this film.  Since I am a Republican and a fan of Rockwell, I am biased.  Nonetheless, why does a real life Horatio Alger story necessarily need to be conservative propoganda?My rebuttal to the critic:  Look beyond the politics and just enjoy the film.  It's a good flick whether you vote GOP or Democrat.

reviews.review_title: Vivid reconstruction of a personal triumph
reviews.content: Despite the many obstacles and personal tragedies along the way, this is an idyllic world carried by nostalgics everywhere.  The parents are noble if at times unsupportive, the friends are true and selfless, the teacher lives for your success, and the whole community is focused on your achievements. Hard work IS rewarded.  You ARE unselfish, humble, and undeniably deserving of every success.The director skillfully orchestrates an emotionally compelling composition. Most of the acting is understated and inoffensive.  Chris Cooper reprises his life role as a courageous but sensitive man pursued by personal demons. Laura Dern is miscast as the supportive teacher.  Jake Gyllenhaal soldiers through an uninspired performance.  The cinematography and plotting, however, is beyond reproach.  Every incident adds to the dramatic intensity and vividness of the picture.  Even if you don't buy the enraptured faces at times, the landscape, homes, and workplaces ring true.  People do help others out of the goodness of their heart and the film glories in these moments of real personal kindness.If you like Norman Rockwell, are over 50, and were caught up in the space race, see the movie.  Check your cynicism at the door for a pleasant escape to a place that feels real, where good and bad are easily defined, and where all the problems are horrific but manageable.

I was inspired, encouraged, and uplifted by this story. Wonderful understated acting by Gyllenhaal and Cooper; especially appreciated their characters' interactions on-screen. It's got dark elements, but you see that the father is essentially a good man who makes mistakes. A great movie, I'd definitely recommend it!

If you are looking for a great movie, look no further, because this one fits the bill.The year is 1957, and the Soviet Union has released Sputnik into space. One night, the citizens of Coalwood, West Virginia, watch the sky to get a view of the satellite. The event has a significant impact on young Homer Hickam.After seeing Sputnik, Homer becomes fascinated with rockets. He strives to learn everything there is to know about them. Joining forces with three other students, production begins on the first rocket.As time passes, the quartet's prowess in constructing rockets improves, and with the encouragement of teacher Frieda Riley, the boys work hard to earn a chance to go to the National Science Fair in Indianapolis.While Homer and his colleagues develop a popular following, there are some who oppose their work. The biggest critic is Homer's father, John, who is a supervisor at the town's coal mine. His belief is simple: Rockets are a waste of time, and Homer should go to work in the mine, which ultimately becomes the career of virtually all of Coalwood's male citizens. As one of the characters says at one point, it's either the mine, or possibly college thanks to a football scholarship.Since Homer cannot play football, it's either the mine, or rockets. He definitely does not want the first option. What will it be? The film has some solid performances, including Jake Gyllenhall as Homer, and Chris Cooper as John. The script is good, and a lot of the scenes evoke the right emotions. You cannot help but cheer for Homer, who has a dream and wants to achieve it.This film is an uplifting drama, and does show that if you believe, you can follow your dreams. Don't miss it.

In October Sky the life of Homer Hickam and his friends (not all characters in the movie were actually Homer's friends) in Coalwood, WV a town that as the name suggests primarily mines coal. During the time that the story takes place the Russians launch Sputnik and Homer suddenly becomes engrossed with rocketry and such. His friends reluctantly help him with doing things with his hobby. Along the way Homer and his friends must overcome people in town who believe they're lunatics and Homer must overcome his gruff father who shows no proud in Homer but centers it on his brother Jim a football star. It is an incredible story about overcoming some fierce odds. Some good acting also helps the film. It was a good film.

reviews.review_title: Heartwarming slice of life in rural West Virginia
reviews.content: I also grew up in a small town in rural WV, about 3 miles from where this movie is set.  Although this movie takes place some twenty years before I grew up, many of the mores still exist.  For instance, in the 70's and early 80's coal mining was still a dominant market force in southern WV.  Both of my grandfathers were coal miners who worked much of their life underground. Children were primed and expected to work in the mines if they intended to continue to live in southern WV as adults.  This movie strikes an interesting and true-to-life account of a typical southern WV coal mining family.  While watching this movie, I felt transported back to my childhood days, remembering what it was like to wonder if I would be relegated to working in the coal mines.  But, like Homer, I too was able to choose a different path except that I had my father's blessing.  Needless to say, I was moved and touched by this movie, however, I do believe there were great things about growing up in the WV mountains that were not explored in the movie.

I love this movie. First of all because my father was an aerospace engineer, specifically in the field of cryogenics. He worked in the space industry from it's inception in the 1950's to his retirement in 1979. He has been referred to as a "space pioneer." Among his last projects were cryogenic designs for the space shuttle orbiter, ground support systems for the shuttle and preliminary designs for the international space station. He authored several magazine articles and a manual that is still used by today's aerospace engineers. His shuttle designs are still used on every shuttle flight more than thirty years after his retirement. One could say that he was a "Rocket boy" himself! Secondly, it is just simply a well made, well acted movie. I watch it every October and never tire of it.

Everything about this movie is perfect! I scannned a few other reviews before I wrote this .... they pretty much said it all, but I did not see a mention of how wonderful the music was - I made a list of songs to get hold of based on this movie!
I guess the story felt "extra-real" for me becuase I was bought up in a similar "company town" environment where the expectation was to "be a man and follow in your father´s footsteps". That pressure is so strong its hard to beleive. Thankfully my farther was against that and encouraged me to break free. If you recognise that kind of scenario, you 100% have to see this film. Even if not, it´s still an awesome film.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies of the past year
reviews.content: While not being as great as Shawshank Redemption, it does have the same feel to it- being emotional, uplifting, and inspiring.  It also is continuing the recent trend of family-friendly movies which are actually good (better than a lot of the trash-mouthed sex-laced flicks that are pushed on us these days).  The father-son relationship is very well done.  While the father seems hard, calloused and completely devoid of any feelings for his son, he does love his son and wants what the best for him.  This movie will probably be a slow burner - even a month after its release, it's slowly gaining word of mouth and selling out theaters.  Go see it.

The film belongs to Inventor - Underdog genre.  Jake Gyllenhaal, Laura Dern and Chris Cooper bring a little acting verve to story with several standard elements. Well filmed, well edited, with plenty of well acted secondary roles.Some have declared this movie to be classic American hokey. It is that and more. I agree with those who say "The movie celebrates the thrill of youthful inspiration." The film is a pleasant reminder that achievement may be born of ordinary roots.

This is a fantastic movie that proves that dreams can come true with faith in yourself and endless perseverance. reviews.review_title: Rocket boys take to the sky
reviews.content: "October Sky" is a pretty good movie with pretty good performances. Maybe even great, but I don't believe that it's one of the greatest family masterpieces it's often made out to be. The story was relatively interesting, starring a young Jake Gyllenhaal as real-life NASA engineer Homer Hickam. After the Soviet satellite Sputnik was sent into space, it instantly caught Hickam's interests and he knew that this was what he was going to do. His family doesn't believe in him, his town doesn't believe in him but one teacher does and it changes his life. I'm sorry, I know this is a true story and all but this movie is very predictable, around the half-way mark you know exactly what's going to happen almost in the order that it ends up doing. That makes the movie feel much longer than it is, probably didn't help that I was also watching it with my family very late at night. They frequently asked me "how much longer?" It's by no means a bad movie, not at all. It's average-length but just seems drawn out as the entire story could've easily been told in the span of 10 minutes. Ah, well. Still pretty good family movie, one of the better ones I think I've actually seen and I'd recommend it actually. I liked it, even though a lot of my sleepy siblings didn't. It's quite an inspiring tale of believing in yourself when no one else would but it just falls a little short for my personal tastes. It's still an excellent family movie though.
