reviews.review_title: Did you ever see Frankenstein and the wolf man?
reviews.content:
Based on the memoir Rocket Boys by Homer H. Hickam Jr., October Sky emerged as one of the most delightful sleepers of 1999--a small miracle of good ol' fashioned movie-making in the cynical, often numbingly trendy Hollywood of the late 20th century. Hickam's true story begins in 1957 with Russia's historic launch of the Sputnik satellite, and while Homer (played with smart idealism by Jake Gyllenhaal) sees Sputnik as his cue to pursue a fascination with rocketry.
Comparisons to "Stand by Me" are unavoidable, since "October Sky" has a small-town intimacy, a group of close-knit pals and the kind of innocence seldom found on screen these days. What it also has is a predictable trajectory that works against such appealing simplicity. As adapted by Lewis Colick, the screenplay shifts busily among the boys' rocket exploits, Homer's family, conditions at the mine and the influence of a dedicated science teacher (Laura Dern), but each of these subplots plays out in familiar ways.The film watches Homer progress from accidentally blowing a hole in the family's white picket fence, which virtually adjoins the mine, to learning how to make a rocket soar. With the aid of his closest buddies (Chris Owen, William Lee Scott and Chad Lindberg), Homer draws on limited local resources for his rocketry experiments. Since this means commandeering metal from railroad tracks and visiting a still for 100-proof rocket fuel, the story has its playful side.
What I especially liked about "October Sky." Even at its most bleak, the film remains hopeful. Colick's screenplay is filled with hope and dreams, and characters who dare to have both. Johnston has corralled an excellent cast to bring this story to life. Jake Gyllenhaal is outstanding as Homer, whose youthful exuberance betrays a maturity way beyond his years. Gyllenhaal's emotional range is incredible, and he says so much with his eyes. All father-son tales need a strong father figure, and "October Sky" has one in Chris Cooper. It would be so easy for Cooper to reduce John Hickam to a cliche, yet he brings much depth to the role.but you know there's more going on than meets the eye. Likewise, Laura Dern is so sweet as Miss Riley you almost miss the small touches she brings to her performance. There's hope in her eyes. Homer's friends are all exceptional, while Natalie Canerday shows great strength as Homer's mom. Director Johnston and his technical crew have done a splendid job of evoking time and place. Even though the film was shot in Tennessee, it looks and feels like West Virginia. John Ford would have been proud of this film. Yes, the message and the delivery may be a little sentimental, yet it works in the films favor. You'll laugh, you'll cry, but most of all, you'll feel good inside, and if that's a crime, then lock me up!
Owen, bespectacled and goofy as the stereotypical math geek, suits the film's taste for typecasting as well as its quaintly 1950s look, which calls for studiously modest props and costumes, and for townsfolk who are often Rockwellishly agog.
In a film that appreciates the advent of "Jailhouse Rock" along with that of Sputnik, "Ain't That a Shame?" accompanies a montage of rockets gone kerflooey. A pretty girl is on hand to sigh, "It sure was exciting watching your rockets go up!"
Gyllenhaal does seem more like the Columbia University freshman he is than the rural West Virginian he plays. But he brings such sincerity to telling his science teacher that a book called "Principles of Guided Missile Design" is the best present he has ever received that his affecting performance is liable to breathe life into science projects everywhere.
But more often the film's tone is just right, and the spirit of adventure and invention is infectiously conveyed through Gyllenhaal and his well-cast fellow rocketeers, whose many failures gradually lead to triumph on their makeshift backwoods launching pad. Capturing time and place with impeccable detail and superbly developed characters (including Laura Dern as an inspiring schoolteacher), October Sky is a family film for the ages, encouraging the highest potential of the human spirit while giving viewers a clear view of a bygone era when "the final frontier" beckoned to the explorer in all of us.
I loved this movie. It is one of the few movies that I have consistently recommended to friends to rent and have had all of them thank me for the referral. The film has some powerful themes that are beautifully scripted.
This is not just another movie it's the one that inspires you to dream!"A single dream is more powerful than a thousand realities." ~ J.R.R.Tolkien

reviews.review_title: A perfect movie for a dark October evening
reviews.content: Maybe not the most original way of telling a story, we've seen all this before in many movies.. but.. I liked it October Sky alot anyways. It got something, Great directing and good acting by all parts, especially Laura Dern(the teacher) and Chris Cooper(the father). I wanna be a rocket-engineer!:)

This movie is one of the top 250 ever made?  Don´t think so.  It wasn´t terrible, though.  I spent a rainy Sunday afternoon in Germany with not a lot to do, so I checked out the Pay-Per-View selections, and chose 'October Sky' over 'Tea With Mussolini', which I am still pretty confident was a good idea.We´ve seen this film before, and it was called 'Hoosiers'.  Or was it "Rudy" The same themes exist:  some backwoods youth or youths overcome adversity and do the un-do-able.  The same characters seem to ring in all these movies:  an overbearing father that thinks his kid is a dern fool; an inspiring role model and encourager...  But it was done much better than this in the aforementioned films "Rudy", and particularly "Hoosiers". "October´s" characters were one dimensional, the dialogue rivalled that of Titanic, and there was not enough detail put into the real rocket-making, in my opinion.  (OK, so I am an engineer... we tend to take the fun out of all science-related movies if they are not fully precise.)But please don´t think I hated it.  This film would be a perfect one to show to middle school and early high school students.  I would have found it inspiring at that age, especially since I was interested in science and enjoyed blowing things up.  So show this to your kids, they will probably enjoy it, and it is not something anyone would walk out of, although I found myself accidentally changing the channel a couple of times (remember, it was PPV!)  But please don´t think you´re about to see Lawrence of Arabia since it is rated in the top 250!

reviews.review_title: The Future Belongs to Science and Hard Work
reviews.content: My wife did not realize what a gem this movie was when she picked it up.  It is a story that shows real world success through hard work and determination.That is so refreshing in a world of violent movies not that I dis-like them), but you have to love a movie that succeeds without it.

Many people have great dreams, but they never have the courage to act on them.  This movie shows what a person with enough passion for his dream can do in the most unlikely circumstances.  A great family movie.  Watch it with your children and show them how they can succeed, no matter what circumstances you and they find yourselves in now.Oh, by the way, the non-G-rated stuff is minimal.

I watched the movie over and over again as it is much of an inspiration not to mention I've shed galleons of tears just to see how they overcome all odds to pursue what they dreamt of as a teen and the inspiration and the ever helping hand of Miss Riley.Our destiny is not a default choice but we made our own choice and our own destiny.Against all odds,four boys with faint hopes of future other than mining coal choose a different path.Only few of the people around them stood by them.Even their close families act as bumps in their journey.No one ever believed in what they do.And against all odds,they did what no one else even dare to dreamt of from Coalwood,a small coal mining county in America.One of my favourite movie of all time.

This is quintessentially the epitome of "when I think of you, in my head movies, my eyes rain."
It is the absolute worst kind of movie.

The beauty of october sky lies in fable like story telling,The film follows the life of Homer Hickam who after seeing sputnik 1 inspires to make rockets.The film deals the efforts of Homer and his friends (Rocket boys).
One of the best parts of the movie is how the movie shows the relation between Homer and his father.Homer's father is shown as a good man ,we see him helping others and it is clear he wants Homer to follow his footsteps in to the mine.But we feel as though he is a little bit unfair towards him.
Homer disagrees with him ,never lets his dream down and breaks free from the coal mine.But even through all this he respects hims father and the considers him his hero.This ought be one of the most honest portrayal of father-son in a movie.
Chris cooper and jake gyllenhall stands out with their portrayal and rest of the cast was good too.soundtrack was great with songs giving tge late 50s vibe.
Altogether october sky is a sweet tale worth watching.A good piece of feel good cinema.

This movie was amazing! Overall, I loved this movie, with excellent acting! Homer wanted to follow his dream and his dad didn't seem to care, except for himself. Yet his father was a self-made successful man in his own way. This is a point in case that go for the golden ring. Tears come to your eyes towards the end.

A fine piece of storytelling with a great cast and direction.It makes one think which is a rarity in this time.This review is a bit late but something's are worth the wait.An interesting bit part was the train engineer, O.Winston Link was a famous photographer of the last days of the steam era of railroads.Amazing photography of a time long remembered,much like this beautiful story.

This movie is very inspiring. It is a great movie based on a true story and is family friendly for all ages. It promotes hard work and knowledge. I enjoyed this movie and it is a great movie for any aspiring engineers showing what people are capable of if they put their minds to it.
October Sky was a joy to watch.  The movie was well written.  The actors were wonderful.  The direction was brilliant. The photography and lighting were great.

I saw this movie at a preview on Feb. 7 after reading the book.  It was quite faithful to the book.  There were a handful of minor differences, and one fairly major difference, but I think they helped to get the story across in the limited time.  Since the book lacked any photographs, except an obscured one on the dust jacket, the photos and home movie clips at the end of the movie of the real people were an interesting addition, and they added a lot to the point that this was a true story.  I was somewhat surprised at how emotional the movie was for me.  I built a lot of model rockets in the '60s and '70s, and the day after seeing the movie I had a good talk with my dad about those times.

I hope Hollywood will take notice of this wonderful film and follow in its creative and beautiful footsteps.  It's touching.  It's fresh.  And it deserves great attention.  What a wonderful story about having a dream and the will to fight for it!  Everyone spread the word, and take the time to be moved. Support this film and maybe more like it will follow.

reviews.review_title: Fiction can never live up to the passion of truth.
reviews.content: I went to this movie expecting to see an engaging movie.  I was blown away by the its power in portraying the interpersonal dynamics of a family more meaningfully and more realistically than any movie I have previously seen. Perhaps this movie hit me this hard because I grew up during this very era, in a small town, with a strong but loving father.This movie should be seen by anyone who has had or will have a relationship with a parent or child.  I'm serious.  This is a movie that parents need to watch once in a while to stay in touch with what parenting can be all about.This movie depicts a father in the multitude of shades in which real fathers exist.  He isn't perfect.  He makes mistakes.  But in the context of this movie, he is so real as to draw you inside the movie screen for the duration of the movie.  Every character in the movie shares in this magic.The casting was perfection.  The acting was superb.  The music is the perfect counterpoint to the drama.  The cinematography was exquisite, giving a color movie a feel and tone that I've only seen brought out in black and white films.  If this movie speaks to you, and I feel it will to most who see it, regardless of age, you won't watch it... you will live it.  You will experience it.This movie is about relationships.  Parent to child.  Brother to brother. It's about growing up, and finding your own way.  It's about the social stratification that occurs in high school.  And in the manner of Joseph Campbell, it's about following your bliss.I went to the movies to be entertained, as only a movie can entertain, and left in wonderment at having experienced one of the ten best movies of the decade.
October Sky surpassed my expectations. It had good characters, good acting, and a good script. I would compare it to the likes of Stand By Me and Hoosiers.

Don't get me wrong, this has all the makings of a crowd-pleaser. Unfortunately, I was not part of that crowd. I was, however, part of a large group of predominantly families at an advance screening. It was, to me, a profoundly above-average family film-- far better than any Disney remake tripe, it was easily digested, with appropriate musical swells, and no surprising plot twists to distract you from the nostalgia. Forgettable for me, but worth watching for those two of you who haven't yet seen Field of Dreams, which had similar themes but was immeasurably more interesting. I must be watching too many Kevin Smith flicks or something, because I was sniggering when some viewers were crying, trying to absorb the uber-sappy dialog without busting up. If you hated Trainspotting, see this the day of its release!

Although this film is set in the hills of appalachia, it contains the elements of experiences that most of us have had growing through those high school years.  I think part of the film's attraction is that one can relive some of past and can relate to those times in which we were able to attain or not achieve our goals.

October Sky is about about the future. Except that it's a future that we already know. You have probably already heard October Sky is another "Field of Dreams." That's not a fair comparison. Field of Dreams was a fantasy about the past. About remembering. In the last few minutes of movie. Ray's daughter talked about how people will come and "remember what it was like."We already know Homer's future. The trailer shows the space shuttle launching. The story is about following a dream sometimes when it would seem not to make sense to do. Not just because you live in a coal town. Homer is more like Matt Damon in "Good Will Hunting." A "fish out of water" who is struggling to understand a dream that few around him are able to nourish.I think I liked the title "Rocket Boys" better (the name of the book). It's more exciting and says something about the people. But, under any name, October Sky is worth taking a look at.

reviews.review_title: Great family entertainment from an ensemble cast
reviews.content: We saw this movie at a sneak preview and the audience, predominantly families, was thoroughly entertained.  The story revolves around a group of 1950s high school students seeking to win a science fair.  It's a good coming-of-age yarn that avoids lapsing onto corny sentimentality too often or easy send-ups of I like Ike era mores.  Particularly good work from Chris Cooper as the father.

reviews.review_title: True story of coal-mining, rockets, and fathers and sons.
reviews.content: For purposes of full disclosure, I grew up in southern West Virginia about 7 miles from the setting of this story, and accordingly I was predisposed to like this movie. That being said, I thought "October Sky" was a wonderful film. A group of coal-town boys discover a passion for rockets after the launch of Sputnik, and use their passion to build a way out of a seemingly inevitable life in the mines. I read the book "Rocket Boys" on which the film is based, and while certain liberties were taken the movie is largely faithful to the events and spirit of the book.

I went to see October Sky not knowing what to expect but I really enjoyed it. A great family film. The cast was perfect . Tell your friends and family to go out and see it. A big thumb up for October Sky!!!!!!!!!!!

reviews.review_title: See this with your friends and/or family!
reviews.content: "October Sky" derives its title from the crisp, clear night sky often viewed over West Virginia in the waining months of any year.  This particular "October Sky" sets the time of the movie as coinciding with the launch of Sputnik -- the first orbiting satellite, which was launched by the Soviet Union.  Because of the technology of the time, the satellite orbited the earth and passed over the United States about every 19-hours.  It could be seen with the naked eye on a clear night, and the wonder of man putting an object into space is keenly opposed to the fear such a device struck in the minds of many citizens during the Cold War.Based on a true story, "October Sky" also chronicles the diametrically opposed views of life -- the wonder of a young man who sees his future involved in the vastness of space and the uncertainty thereof, and the concern of his father for his son's future -- determined that it will be solidly anchored in the constant of coal mining (confined space and underground).This film celebrates the wonderment of dreaming and the freedom to both pursue and succeed at that dream.  It is an impremartyr of the human spirit in a world free to overcome restraints.  When you leave the theater, the viewer may feel pleasant contentment that nice guys CAN win.

I was an extra in this movie and I was so pleased with the end product.  I was very eager to see how it would look on screen, since I saw some of the behind the scenes work.  The story was great and the movie was so inspirational.  Everyone should see this movie, especially young people who need a little inspiring.  Fantastic!!!!!!

Growing up in the coal fields of Virginia/West Virginia I was extremely impressed to see a movie that actually took the reality of life and put it on the big screen.  There were no big special effects, none of the "hollywood glitz and glamour" or any of those action sequences that leave you wondering what just happened.  The mines sequences were very realistic, and even the death of a miner was portrayed with the perfection.  It was a straight forward, wonderful movie about the life of four young boys growing up in West Virginia. The only problem I had with the film was the casting of Miss Riley as a glamorous blond, instead of the pretty brunette that she was (just look at her when they show the home videos at the end).  Of course, that only bothers me because she's my cousin, no one else in the world really cares.  Overall, the movie was one of those films that drew me in.  It left me wanting more. Although it was under two hours, the movie is well worth the six dollars you would have to pay to see it.  Go out of your way for this one.  It's probably the best of '99 so far.  And don't forget to read the book...it should also be a hit.

reviews.review_title: A moving and inspirational piece of film.
reviews.content: A few times a year a truly inspirational film comes out, this is the first of '99. It follows the true story of Homer Hickam (Gyllenhaal) and his obsession with building rockets to go out into space. His infatuation pulls in his friends and a nerdy social outcast (Owen) and together they all get the nickname "The Rocket Boys". Through all the turmoil of trying to break out of their small coal mining hometown these boys prevail. One of the greatest obstacles that Homer had to go through was the views of his own father (Cooper) who thought what Homer wanted was only pipe dreams and that coal mining was going to be his life. This is a true story of overcoming opposition by all this world's forces.Gyllenhaal does a terrific job as our hometown hero. His youthful determination and strength plows through the screen and into your heart. The reality of Homer just makes his efforts in this movie more of an homage to the real man than just another role. Gyllenhaal treats it with the perfect amount of dignity and pride. The other impressive performace came from Cooper in his portrayal of Homer's coal mining father. The sheer hardness of his attitude towards Homer and his dreams matched the very coal he pulled from beneath the ground. He did show some admirable qualities throughout the film which gave the audience just enough reason to not write him off entirely as an uncaring and ignorant hick. Then at the end he opens his character up to the true depth of the love between a father and son.The direction and cinematography of this picture was beautiful throughout in not only its scenes of Homer's exciting rockets but also in the bleakness of life in a coal mining town. Johnston truly captured the harsh and heavy nature of mining life and the effects that it can have on those people and their families. This detailed very well the hard sacrifices that some people have to make in life just to survive.Recommendation: If you are looking for inspiration then look here. You can walk of this movie feeling that whatever it is that you want to do with your life can be done. The fact that this is a true story shows that your own circumstances could be far worse and that anyone can follow their dreams to the end. This type of motivational power hasn't been seen since Rocky.

reviews.review_title: The best movie to come along in a decade!
reviews.content: This is the best movie I've seen in years!  The fact that it's a true story makes it even better, and this movie shows what Hollywood can do when they set their formulaic pseudo-sophistication aside and really try.  "Glory" was the best movie made, in my opinion, until now.  "October Sky" is at least as good.  A must see for anyone with a heart!

reviews.review_title: Maybe the best film for the entire family you'll see this year!
reviews.content: A true and inspiring story about a coal town teen who, stubbornly, would not give up his dream of becoming a rocket scientist.I rated this film a "10", not because it's a flawless film -- it isn't (main criticism being that it's predictable).  But it has a clear storyline, excellent acting, a "moral", and some heart-rending realization and growth on the part of the characters.  What impressed me the most was that this was truly a film for an entire family that was not silly, or reliant on special effects.  It appeals on multiple levels.After a day or two thinking about this movie, I realized, what more can you expect from a motion picture?  Not much--which explains the 10 rating.I'm predicting this will be the sleeper hit of 1999.

reviews.review_title: Excellent coming-of-age and triumph over obstacles film.
reviews.content: This movie owes a lot to STAND BY ME and BREAKING AWAY (and even HOW GREEN WAS MY VALLEY)....pretty good company, but it manages to stand alone. Performances across the board are excellent.It catches the spirit of the times (1957) which I happen to be old enough to remember, the first reaction to Sputnik, the grim reality of a coal mine town.  Ultimately, however, it is the story of one young man who reaches beyond the stars and succeeds.What keeps it from being  mawkish is the fact that is it grounded in truth and feels like it.

Having spent my high school years in a small Tennesse town, I really saw glimpses of myself and my friends in October Sky.  This is a movie that reminds us all what it's like to have a dream and what it means to have the courage and determination to pursue the dream, as implausable as it may seem.October Sky has to be one of the best movies I have seen in a while.  The story is simple, but beutifully told, well acted, and thought provoking. Many times Appalachia is portrayed as as isolated area with no chance of leaving, of following any dream. October Sky changes all that.  Sometimes, true stories are the best ones that make it to the screen.The realistic portrayal of Appalachian people is one of the film's strongest selling points.  It presents us in a postive, yet realistic light.  All the accents seemed authentic.  None of those dreadful Hollywood accents that reek with magnolia blossoms.  The conflict between father and son, the fear and excitement of leaving home, the bonds of friendship--all of these shine in this movie.  This film has humor, intelligence, drama and emotion. It is well deserving of accolades!

reviews.review_title: It will leave you with a happy glow in your eyes and an inspired spirit.
reviews.content: In the face of adversity, Homer Hickam never gave up.  He is an inspiration to all that have challenges, and recaptures the incredible feeling of overcoming them.  I found myself still in my seat as the credits rolled down the big screen of this true story.

reviews.review_title: Wonderful movie for many different people
reviews.content: My husband and I saw this movie and both loved it.  We have VERY different tastes in movies, so it says a lot that we both found it to be far above average.  It was just an over-all great movie!
